revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox Film Festival | name = Toronto After Dark Film Festival | image = Toronto After Dark Film Festival.jpg | caption = | number = | founded = 2006 | location = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada | language = [[English language|English]] | website = {{url|www.torontoafterdark.com}} }}
'''Toronto After Dark Film Festival''' is a showcase of [[Horror film|horror]], [[Science fiction film|sci-fi]], [[Action film|action]] and [[Cult film|cult cinema]] held annually in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. The festival premieres a diverse selection of feature-length and short-films from around the world including new works from Asia, Europe and North America.
==Past festivals==
===2006===
The inaugural festival was held October 20–24, 2006, at the [[Bloor Cinema]] in [[Toronto, Ontario]], Canada. The festival showcased 13 feature films from around the world, and 15 short films from Canada. Some of the films screened at the festival included ''[[Special (film)|Special]]'', directed by [[Hal Haberman]] and [[Jeremy Passmorewhere]], the [[J-horror]] film ''[[Retribution (2006 film)|Retribution]]'' from cult director [[Kiyoshi Kurosawa]], the North American premiere of the Thai action-horror film ''[[Vengeance (2006 film)|Vengeance]]'', and ''[[Behind the Mask: The Rise of Leslie Vernon]]'', which won the festival's first Audience Award.
Other films included ''[[The Beach Party at the Threshold of Hell]]'', ''[[Shinobi: Heart Under Blade]]'', ''[[Night of the Living Dorks]]'', ''[[Re-cycle]]'', ''[[Mad Cowgirl]]'', ''[[Slaughter Night]]'', and ''[[Naisu no mori: The First Contact]]''. The festival also featured a "Make Your Own Damn Movie!" masterclass taught by [[Lloyd Kaufman]]. Festival attendance was 4,350.
===2007===
The second annual festival was held from October 19–25, 2007, at the Bloor Cinema. The festival expanded to fifty films: fourteen features and 36 short films from around the world, including 15 Canadian shorts. Festival highlights included ''[[The Tripper]]'', directed by [[David Arquette]]; director [[Shinya Tsukamoto]]'s ''[[Nightmare Detective]]''; the premiere of [[Troma Entertainment]]'s ''[[Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead]]''; [[Uwe Boll]]'s ''[[In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale]]''; the zombie-western short film ''[[It Came From The West]]''; the world premiere of [[John Bergin]]'s ''[[From Inside]]''; ''[[Mulberry Street (film)|Mulberry Street]]'', which went on to win the festival's After Dark Spirit Award; and the Thai horror film ''[[Alone (2007 film)|Alone]]'' from directors [[Banjong Pisanthanakun]] and [[Parkpoom Wongpoom]], which won the festival's annual Audience Award. Festival attendance was 6,500.
Other films included ''[[Blood Car]]'', ''[[Volkodav from the Grey Hound Clan (film)|Wolfhound]]'', ''[[The Rebel (2007 Vietnamese film)|The Rebel]]'', ''[[Audience of One (film)|Audience of One]]'', ''[[Aachi & Ssipak]]'', ''[[Ambassador's Day]]'', ''[[Murder Party]]'', ''[[Operation Fish]]'', ''[[Terror On The 3918]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://culturatti.com/2007/10/30/the-self-esteem-awards-toronto-after-dark-2007-the-shorts |title=The Self-Esteem Awards: Toronto After Dark 2007 — The Shorts |date=30 October 2007 |author=Beal |website=The Culturatti |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509083652/http://culturatti.com/2007/10/30/the-self-esteem-awards-toronto-after-dark-2007-the-shorts |archivedate=9 May 2008 |accessdate=2014-09-06}}</ref> ''[[Simon Says (film)|Simon Says]]'', among others.
===2008===
The third annual festival expanded to eight nights and was held from October 17–24, 2008, at the Bloor Cinema. Highlights of the third Annual Festival included sell-out screenings of ''[[Let the Right One In (film)|Let the Right One In]]'', ''[[Repo! The Genetic Opera]]'', ''[[Tokyo Gore Police]]'', and the North American Premiere of ''[[I Sell The Dead]]''; over 30 attending filmmakers on stage to introduce their films, including [[Larry Fessenden]] (''The Last Winter'') and [[Angus Scrimm]] (''Phantasm''); packed nightly social events; positive reviews for the films programmed; and a ''[[Zombie Walk]]''. Other films included ''[[Trailer Park of Terror]]'', ''[[Mirageman]]'', ''[[Idiots and Angels]]'', ''[[Who is KK Downey?]]'', ''[[4bia]]'', ''Brain Dead'', ''[[Donkey Punch]]'', ''[[Mutant Chronicles (film)|Mutant Chronicles]]'', and ''[[Home Movie (2008 film)|Home Movie]]''. The festival also featured a Make Your Own Damn Movie! masterclass taught by [[Lloyd Kaufman]]. Festival attendance was over 8,500.
Over 3,500 votes were cast for the Audience Award for Best Feature Film and the Gold winner was Swedish vampire film ''[[Let the Right One In (film)|Let the Right One In]]''. Silver went to cult sci-fi horror musical ''[[Repo! The Genetic Opera]]'', and Bronze was awarded by fans to the Thai supernatural anthology movie ''[[4bia]]'' (''Phobia''). Awards were also handed out for Best Independent Feature Film, where the big winner was the grave-robber comedy, ''[[I Sell The Dead]]'', and in the short film categories, winners included the Christmas tree exploitation film ''Treevenge''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.treevenge.com/ |title=Treevenge |publisher=Yer Dead Productions |quote=Audience Award for Best Short Film @ Toronto After Dark Festival |accessdate=2014-09-12}}</ref>
===2009===
The fourth annual festival made the move to summer, and was held August 14–21, 2009, once again at the Bloor Cinema with over 9,000 fans attending the festival. Highlights included screenings of the Norwegian Nazi zombie horror-comedy ''[[Dead Snow]]'', the horror anthology ''[[Trick 'r Treat]]'' and the cult [[blaxploitation]] action-comedy ''[[Black Dynamite]]'', which won Gold, Silver and Bronze respectively in the Audience Choice Awards. The festival also hosted its first ever world premiere, ''[[Strigoi (film)|Strigoi]]'', an offbeat Romanian vampire comedy that was awarded by the fest Gold in the Best Independent Feature Film category. Silver and Bronze honours went to the dark comedy ''[[The Revenant (2009 film)|The Revenant]]'' and the zombie thriller, ''[[Grace (2009 film)|Grace]]'', respectively.
Other films included ''[[Vampire Girl vs. Frankenstein Girl]]'', ''[[The Warlords]]'' (starring Jet Li, Andy Lau and Takeshi Kaneshiro), ''[[Black (Film 2008)|Black]]'' (starring MC Jean Gab'1), ''Rough Cut'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.torontoafterdark.com/2009/feature-films/rough-cut/ |title=2009 Program: Rough Cut |publisher=Toronto After Dark Film Festival |accessdate=2014-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018111538/http://torontoafterdark.com/2009/feature-films/rough-cut/ |archivedate=2012-10-18 |df= }}</ref> ''[[Franklyn]]'' (starring Ryan Phillippe and Eva Green), ''The Forbidden Door'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.torontoafterdark.com/2009/feature-films/the-forbidden-door/ |title=2009 Program: The Forbidden Door |publisher=Toronto After Dark Film Festival |accessdate=2014-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018111550/http://torontoafterdark.com/2009/feature-films/the-forbidden-door/ |archivedate=2012-10-18 |df= }}</ref> ''Must Love Death'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.torontoafterdark.com/2009/feature-films/must-love-death/ |title=2009 Program: Must Love Death |publisher=Toronto After Dark Film Festival |accessdate=2014-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018111557/http://torontoafterdark.com/2009/feature-films/must-love-death/ |archivedate=2012-10-18 |df= }}</ref> ''[[Someone's Knocking at the Door]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.torontoafterdark.com/2009/feature-films/someones-knocking-at-the-door/ |title=2009 Program: Someone's Knocking at the Door |publisher=Toronto After Dark Film Festival |accessdate=2014-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018111533/http://torontoafterdark.com/2009/feature-films/someones-knocking-at-the-door/ |archivedate=2012-10-18 |df= }}</ref> ''[[The Children (2008 film)|The Children]]'', ''[[Embodiment of Evil]]'' (the third film in the ''[[Coffin Joe]]'' trilogy), and ''[[The Dark Hour (2007 film)|The Dark Hour]]''. ''Shorts After Dark (International Short Film Snowcase)'' comprised eleven new horror, sci-fi, action, and cult short films from around the world, including a number of international award winners.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.torontoafterdark.com/2009/shorts-after-dark-international-short-film-showcase/ |title=2009 Program: Shorts After Dark (International Short Film Showcase) |publisher=Toronto After Dark Film Festival |accessdate=2014-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308000545/http://www.torontoafterdark.com/2009/shorts-after-dark-international-short-film-showcase/ |archivedate=2012-03-08 |df= }}</ref> ''Canada After Dark (Canadian Short Film Snowcase)'' featured 17 "home-grown" short films (and are the opening acts for the feature films).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.torontoafterdark.com/2009/canada-after-dark-canadian-short-film-showcase/ |title=2009 Program: Canada After Dark (Canadian Short Film Showcase) |publisher=Toronto After Dark Film Festival |accessdate=2014-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308000550/http://www.torontoafterdark.com/2009/canada-after-dark-canadian-short-film-showcase/ |archivedate=2012-03-08 |df= }}</ref>
===2010===
The fifth annual festival was held August 13–20, 2010,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thetfs.ca/2010/07/29/toronto-after-dark-film-fest-lineup-announced/ |last=Fossen |first=Pam |title=Toronto After Dark Film Fest Lineup Announced! |date=29 July 2010 |website=Toronto Film Scene |accessdate=2014-09-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.torontoafterdark.com/2010/index.php/updates/view/toronto-after-dark-film-fest-announces-complete-2010-lineup-includes-fre/ |title=Toronto After Dark Announces 2010 Lineup: HUMAN CENTIPEDES, Killer RUBBER Tires, Deadly ROBOGEISHAS! |date=30 July 2010 |publisher=Toronto After Dark Film Festival |accessdate=2014-09-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140911050546/http://www.torontoafterdark.com/2010/index.php/updates/view/toronto-after-dark-film-fest-announces-complete-2010-lineup-includes-fre/ |archivedate=11 September 2014 |df= }}</ref> once again at the Bloor Cinema with over 9,300 fans attending. Highlights included the festival's first-ever red carpet premiere for ''[[The Last Exorcism]]'', with producer Eli Roth, stars Ashley Bell and Patrick Fabian attending, the horror film ''[[The Human Centipede]]'', and the 2010 remake of the 1978 exploitation film ''[[I Spit on Your Grave (2010 film)|I Spit On Your Grave]]''. These three films won Gold, Silver and Bronze respectively, in the Audience Choice Awards.
Other films included ''[[The Last Lovecraft: Relic of Cthulhu]]'', ''[[Doghouse (film)|Doghouse]]'', ''[[Evil - In the Time of Heroes|Evil In the Time of Heroes]]'', ''[[RoboGeisha|Robogeisha]]'', ''[[Alien vs Ninja]]'', ''[[Phobia 2]]'', ''[[Cargo (2009 film)|Cargo]]'', ''[[Centurion (film)|Centurion]]'', ''[[Black Death (film)|Black Death]]'', ''[[All About Evil]]'', ''[[High School (2010 film)|High School]]'' and ''[[Rubber (2010 film)|Rubber]]''.
''Shorts After Dark (International Short Film Snowcase)'' comprised 10 new horror, sci-fi, action, and cult short films from around the world, including a number of international award winners and premieres.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.torontoafterdark.com/2010/index.php/shorts-after-dark/ |title=2010 Program: Shorts After Dark (International Short Film Showcase) |publisher=Toronto After Dark Film Festival |accessdate=2014-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903191732/http://www.torontoafterdark.com/2010/index.php/shorts-after-dark/ |archivedate=2014-09-03 |df= }}</ref> 2010's Best International Short Film award winners included ''Off Season'' (Gold), ''[[Pumzi]]'' (Silver), and ''Deus Irae'' (Bronze). ''Canada After Dark (Canadian Short Film Snowcase)'' featured 16 "home-grown" short films (and are the opening acts for the feature films).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.torontoafterdark.com/2010/index.php/canada-after-dark/ |title=2010 Program: Canada After Dark (Canadian Short Film Showcase) |publisher=Toronto After Dark Film Festival |accessdate=2014-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229165259/http://torontoafterdark.com/2010/index.php/canada-after-dark/ |archivedate=2012-02-29 |df= }}</ref> 2010's Best Canadian Short Film award winners included ''Junko's Shamisen'' (Gold),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.junko-film.com/Junkos_Shamisen/screenings.html |title=Screenings |publisher=Artbeast Productions |quote=Audience Choice (Gold) Toronto After Dark Film Festival |accessdate=2014-09-12}}</ref> ''King Chicken'' (Silver), and ''Fireman'' and ''Game Night'' (tied for Bronze).
===2011=== [[Image:Monster Brawl cast and crew.jpg|thumb|right|Cast and crew of the film ''Monster Brawl'' at the gala opening of the 2011 festival.]]
The sixth annual festival returned to October and the Halloween season for the first time in three years, taking place October 20–27, 2011, at the Toronto Underground Cinema. A record number of feature films and short film submissions were received this year.
Toronto After Dark announced the first eight Official Selections of its 2011 film line-up at [[Fan Expo Canada]] on August 25, 2011, then on its official website on August 31, 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://torontoafterdark.com/2011/updates/view/first-titles-announced/ |title=First Titles Announced: MONSTER BRAWL Gala! FATHER'S DAY Premiere! Japanese Thrill-Ride REDLINE! |date=31 August 2011 |publisher=Toronto After Dark Film Festival |accessdate=2014-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903125948/http://torontoafterdark.com/2011/updates/view/first-titles-announced/ |archivedate=3 September 2014 |df= }}</ref> The films selected included ''[[Monster Brawl]]''; ''Exit Humanity'', a zombie saga set against the back-drop of the [[American Civil War]]; the Canadian Premiere of the Pierce Brothers' ''[[Deadheads (film)|DeadHeads]]'', a multi-genre zombie buddy film; ''[[Redline (2009 film)|Redline]]'', a Japanese [[anime]] set in the world of car racing; ''[[The Theatre Bizarre]]'', a horror anthology from such genre filmmakers as [[Tom Savini]] and [[Richard Stanley (film director)|Richard Stanley]]; the World Premiere of ''Father's Day'', a exploitation/grindhouse story from [[Astron-6]] and [[Troma]]; ''[[Love (2011 film)|Love]]'', a time-travel sci-fi drama; and [[Xavier Gens]]'s ''[[The Divide (2011 film)|The Divide]]'', an apocalyptic film about the residents of a New York City apartment building.
Toronto After Dark was honoured in hosting two more World Premiere screenings. The WWII action-horror-zombie film, ''[[War of the Dead]]'', directed by Marko Mäkilaakso and the dark, superhero thriller, ''[[Vs (film)|VS]]'', directed by Jason Trost (co-writer, director, and star of ''THE FP'') and starring [[James Remar]].
Other films include the ''Jack Perez''{{'}}s horror comedy, ''Some Guy Who Kills People'', starring [[Kevin Corrigan]], the vampire-drama, ''[[Midnight Son]]'', the award-winning supernatural thriller, ''[[Absentia (film)|Absentia]]'', the action-thriller, ''[[A Lonely Place to Die]]'', [[Astron-6]]'s sci-fi, action-comedy, ''[[Manborg]]'', the Canadian sci-fi thriller, ''The Corridor'', [[Lucky McKee]]'s controversial film ''[[The Woman (2011 film)|The Woman]]'', and [[Ti West]]'s haunted hotel thriller, ''[[The Innkeepers (film)|The Innkeepers]]''.
[[Astron-6]]'s ''Father's Day'', ''[[The Divide (2011 film)|The Divide]]'' and ''[[Deadheads (film)|DeadHeads]]'' won Gold, Silver and Bronze respectively, in the Audience Choice Awards for Best Feature Film.
===2012===
The seventh annual festival saw the Toronto After Dark Film Festival return to the recently reopened and renovated Bloor Cinema October 18–26, 2012. The festival also expanded one extra night, showcasing a total of twenty feature films and a wealth of Canadian and International short films. The Toronto After Dark Film Festival hosted two ''Spotlight Presentation'' Screening Nights Summer 2012, taking place also at Bloor Cinema, Wednesday, June 27 and Wednesday, July 11. These two evenings showcased two films each night, including ''[[Juan of the Dead]]'', ''[[The Pact (2012 film)|The Pact]]'', ''[[Detention (2011 film)|Detention]]'' and the Canadian Premiere of ''[[V/H/S]]''.
The 2012 Toronto After Dark Film Festival Official Selections included the Canadian Premiere of the body-modification thriller ''[[American Mary]]'', from Vancouver-based writers, producers and directors, Sylvia and Jen Soska (otherwise known as the [[Soska sisters]]). Other selections included, the Irish alien-monster horror-comedy ''[[Grabbers]]''; the dark crime-thriller ''[[Crave (film)|Crave]]'', directed by DVD and Blu-ray producer and filmmaker, [[Charles de Lauzirika]]; the British horror film ''[[Inbred (film)|Inbred]]''; the third installment of the ''[[REC (film)|REC series]]'', ''[[REC 3: Génesis]]''; the British zombie-comedy ''[[Cockneys vs Zombies]]''; ''[[Honor Blackman]]''; the South Korean science-fiction anthology film ''[[Doomsday Book (film)|Doomsday Book]]''; the Canadian ''[[LARP|"LARP"-ing]]'' comedy ''[[Lloyd the Conqueror|Lloyd The Conqueror]]''; the latest UniSol installment, ''[[Universal Soldier: Day of Reckoning]]''; the dark fantasy-thriller ''[[After (2012 film)|After]]''; the paranormal sequel ''[[Grave Encounters 2]]''; the Irish psychological-horror film ''[[Citadel (film)|Citadel]]'', from director, [[Ciaran Foy]]; the documentary ''My Amityville Horror'', in which Daniel Lutz, one of the children who lived through ''[[Amityville Horror|The Amityville Horror]]'', is interviewed; ''[[Resolution (film)|Resolution]]'', directed by Justin Benson and Aaron Moorhead; ''[[Tony Todd]]'', ''[[Mark Hamill]]'', ''[[Noah Hathaway]]'', ''[[James Duval]]'' and newcomer, [[Cortney Palm]], highlight Kern Saxton's revenge crime-thriller, ''[[Sushi Girl]]''; Japanese director, [[Noboru Iguchi]]'s comedy-horror, ''[[Dead Sushi]]''; the home-invasion thriller ''[[In their skin|In Their Skin]]''; and ''[[Wrong (film)|Wrong]]'', the latest film from ''[[Mr. Oizo|Quentin Dupieux (aka Mr. Oizo)]]''.
''[[A Fantastic Fear of Everything]]'', starring ''[[Simon Pegg]]'', and Juan Martínez Moreno's Spanish werewolf-comedy, ''[[Game of Werewolves|Game of Werewolves (Lobos de Arga)]]'', rounded out the closing night of the festival.
''[[Cockneys vs Zombies]]'', ''[[Dead Sushi]]'' and ''[[A Fantastic Fear of Everything]]'' won Gold, Silver and Bronze respectively, in the Audience Choice Awards for Best Feature Film.
===2013===
The eighth annual festival sees the Toronto After Dark Film return once again this year, October 17–25, 2013. This year the festival partnered up with Canada's Cineplex Entertainment, with the [[Scotiabank Theatre Toronto|Scotiabank Theatre]] hosting the festival.
The Toronto After Dark Film Festival hosted two pre-festival Screening Nights Summer 2013, taking place also at the Scotiabank Theatre, Thursday, August 29 and Thursday, September 26. These two evenings showcased two films each night, including ''[[Bad Milo]]''; ''[[V/H/S/2]]''; the Canadian Premiere of ''[[Europa Report]]'' and, ''[[The Dirties]]''.
The 2013 Toronto After Dark Film Festival Official Selections included the Opening Gala film and Toronto Premiere of [[Jim Mickle]]'s ''[[We Are What We Are (2013 film)|We Are What We Are]]''. This marked a return to Toronto After Dark for Mickle, as his 2006 film, ''[[Mulberry Street (film)|Mulberry Street]]'' was a previous Toronto After Dark Official Selection. Other returning Toronto After Dark alumni for 2013 included Henry Saine with ''[[Bounty Killer (film)|Bounty Killer]]'' and Jesse T. Cook with ''Septic Man'' for the Canadian Premiere. Other selections included creature features ''[[Big Ass Spider!]]'' and ''[[Eega]]''; the British zombie-comedy ''[[Stalled]]''; the zombie-drama ''[[The Battery (2012 film)|The Battery]]'', directed by Jeremy Gardner; the World Premiere of the Canadian thriller ''Silent Retreat'', directed by ''Tricia Lee''; Don Thacker's ''Motivational Growth''; the Canadian Premiere of ''[[Odd Thomas (film)|Odd Thomas]]'', directed by [[Stephen Sommers]] based on the novels by [[Dean Koontz]]; the Canadian horror-thriller ''[[Solo (2013 film)|Solo]]''; the sci-fi films ''[[Last Days on Mars|The Last Days on Mars]]'' and ''[[The Machine (film)|The Machine]]'', directed by Caradog W. James; the Toronto premiere of ''Found'', directed by Scott Schrimer; the World Premiere of the Canadian action-horror-dark comedy film ''Evil Feed'', directed by Kimani Ray Smith; the Bigfoot found-footage thriller ''[[Willow Creek (film)|Willow Creek]]'', directed by [[Bobcat Goldthwait]]; and Blair Erickson's ''[[Banshee Chapter]]''.
''[[Cheap Thrills (film)|Cheap Thrills]]'' rounded out the closing night of the festival along with ''[[Big Bad Wolves]]'', a dark crime-thriller from Israel directed by [[Aharon Keshales]] and [[Navot Papushado]], selected as the Closing Gala film; [[Quentin Tarantino]] called it the best film of 2013.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}}
''The Battery'', ''Solo'' and ''Banshee Chapter'' won Gold, Silver and Bronze respectively in the Audience Choice Awards for Best Feature Film.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.torontoafterdark.com/2013/award-winners |title=AWARD WINNERS Announced for Toronto After Dark 2013! Zombie film BATTERY, fly revenge EEGA Win Big! |date=1 November 2013 |publisher=Toronto After Dark Film Festival |accessdate=2014-09-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140910231354/http://www.torontoafterdark.com/2013/award-winners |archivedate=10 September 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.space.ca/article/TAD-2013-award-winners |title=Toronto After Dark award winners announced |author=Eleni |date=5 November 2013 |website=[[Space (Canadian TV channel)|Space]] |accessdate=2014-09-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201173037/http://www.space.ca/article/TAD-2013-award-winners |archivedate=1 February 2014 |df= }}</ref>
===2014===
The ninth annual festival saw the Toronto After Dark Film return, October 16–24, 2014. For the second year in a row, the festival partnered up with Canada's Cineplex Entertainment, with the Scotiabank Theatre location once again hosting the festival.
The 2014 Toronto After Dark Film Festival Official Selections included the Opening Gala film and Toronto premiere of Gerard Johnstone's ''[[Housebound]]''. Other selections included ''[[Suburban Gothic (film)|Suburban Gothic]]'', directed by Richard Bates Jr. (''[[Excision (film)|Excision]]'') and starring [[Matthew Gray Gubler]], [[Kat Dennings]] and [[Ray Wise]]; the World premiere of the Canadian film, ''[[Hellmouth (film)|Hellmouth]]'', directed by Toronto After Dark Alumni, John Geddes (''Exit Humanity''), written by [[Tony Burgess (author)|Tony Burgess]] (''[[Pontypool (film)|Pontypool]]'') and starring [[Stephen McHattie]]; the Canadian premiere of ''[[ABCs of Death 2]]'', directed by several Toronto After Dark Alumni, such as [[Soska sisters|Jen Soska and Sylvia Soska]] (''[[American Mary]]''), [[Julian Gilbey]] (''[[A Lonely Place to Die]]''), Steven Kostanski (''[[Manborg]]'') and Juan Martínez Moreno (''[[Lobos de Arga|Game of Werewolves]]''); ''[[Zombeavers]]'', who in turn are trying to eat Toronto After Dark alumni actress, [[Cortney Palm]] (''[[Sushi Girl]]''); Nazi zombies return in the sequel ''[[Dead Snow: Red vs. Dead|Dead Snow 2: Red vs. Dead]]'', directed by Toronto After Dark alumni, [[Tommy Wirkola]]; the Canadian 'splasher' film ''[[The Drownsman]]'', directed by [[Chad Archibald]] (''Neverlost'', ''Antisocial'' and ''[[Ejecta (film)|Ejecta]]''); the North American Premiere of ''[[Wolves (2014 film)|Wolves]]'', directed by [[David Hayter]] (best known as the voice of Solid Snake from the ''[[Metal Gear Solid]]'' video games); ''[[Late Phases]]'', directed by Adrián García Bogliano (''[[Here Comes the Devil|Here Comes the Devil (Ahí va el diablo)]]''), and starring [[Nick Damici]], [[Ethan Embry]] and [[Lance Guest]]; [[Elijah Wood]] and [[Sasha Grey]] star in ''[[Open Windows (film)|Open Windows]]'', directed by [[Nacho Vigalondo]] (''[[Timecrimes|Timecrimes (Los cronocrímenes)]]''); [[Rinko Kikuchi]] stars in ''[[Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter]]''; ''[[Predestination (film)|Predestination]]'', directed by [[Spierig brothers|Michael Spierig and Peter Spierig]] and starring ''[[Ethan Hawke]]''; Bradley King's ''[[Time Lapse (film)|Time Lapse]]'', starring [[Danielle Panabaker]]; the Canadian premiere of ''[[Refuge (2013 film)|Refuge]]'', directed by Andrew Robertson; the Canadian premiere of the Australian zombie-action-comedy ''[[Wyrmwood]]'', directed by Kiah Roache-Turner; the Canadian premiere of ''[[The Town That Dreaded Sundown (2014 film)|The Town That Dreaded Sundown]]'', a meta-sequel of the 1976 film, directed by [[Alfonso Gomez-Rejon]]; and the Canadian premiere of the documentary ''[[Why Horror?]]''
The UK film ''Let Us Prey'', starring ''[[The Woman (2011 film)|The Woman]]'''s [[Pollyanna McIntosh]] rounded out the closing night of the festival, along with ''[[The Babadook]]'', a creepy psychological-horror from Australia directed by [[Jennifer Kent]], selected as the Closing Gala film.
''[[Dead Snow: Red vs. Dead|Dead Snow 2: Red vs. Dead]]'', ''[[Predestination (film)|Predestination]]'' and ''[[Why Horror?]]'' won Gold, Silver and Bronze respectively in the Audience Choice Awards for Best Feature Film.<ref name="torontoafterdark.com">{{cite web|url=http://torontoafterdark.com/2014/awards/|website=Torontoafterdark.com|title=2014 awards|date=2014|archivedate=November 3, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141103121843/http://torontoafterdark.com/2014/awards/}}</ref>
The Canadian short films screened during the festival include, ''Foxed!'', ''Young Blood'', ''Pupa'', ''Lumberjacked'', ''Day 40'', ''Period Piece'', ''Kismet'', ''Rose In Bloom'', ''Dead Hearts'', ''The Monitor'', ''Migration'', ''What Doesn't Kill You'', ''Honor Code'', ''Monster Island'', ''Lazy Boyz'', ''Satan's Dolls'', ''Last Breath'', ''Little Matthew'' and ''Intruders''.
''Period Piece'', ''Dead Hearts'' and ''Satan's Dolls'' won Gold, Silver and Bronze respectively in the Audience Choice Awards for Best Canadian Short Film.<ref name="torontoafterdark.com"/>
The International short films screened during the festival include, ''Invaders'', ''Everything and Everything and Everything'', ''Sword fights'', ''Happy B-Day'', ''Strange Thing'', ''He Took Off His Skin For Me'', ''Liquid'', ''Redaction'' and ''Dynamic Venus''.
''Invaders'', ''Happy B-Day'' and ''He Took Off His Skin For Me'' won Gold, Silver and Bronze respectively in the Audience Choice Awards for Best International Short Film.<ref name="torontoafterdark.com"/>
===2015===
The Toronto After Dark Film Festival took place on October 15–23, 2015, marking the festival's tenth anniversary.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}
The movies posted on the Toronto After Dark Film Festival website for 2015 were: Tales of Halloween, The Hallow, Synchronicity, Lazer Team, Night of the Living Deb, A Christmas Horror Story, Shut In, The Hollow One, The Demolisher, The Diabolical, The Interior, Backtrack, Gridlocked, Nina Forever, The Hexecutioners, Tag, Love & Peace, Patchwork, and Deathgasm.
===2016=== The festival took place October 13 – 21 at the [[Scotiabank Theatre (Toronto)|Scotiabank Theatre]]. The films screened iwere ''[[Under The Shadow]]'', ''[[Trash Fire]]'', ''[[War On Everyone]]'', ''[[Let Her Out]]'', ''[[The Rezort]]'', ''[[Train To Busan]]'', ''[[Kill Command]]'', ''[[In A Valley of Violence]]'', ''[[Blood Father]]'', ''[[I Am Not a Serial Killer]]'', ''[[Bed Of The Dead]]'', ''[[As The Gods Will]]'', ''[[Creepy (film)|Creepy]]'', ''[[Antibirth]]'', ''[[Stake Land 2]]'', ''[[The Master Cleanse]]'', ''[[From A House On Willow Street]]'', ''[[The Lure (2015 film)|The Lure]]'' and ''[[The Void (2016 film)|The Void]]''.<ref name="tadsched">{{cite web |publisher=Toronto After Dark Film Festival |title=2016 Toronto After Dark Film Festival Schedule Flyer |url=https://www.scribd.com/document/327475125/2016-Toronto-After-Dark-Film-Festival-Schedule-Flyer#download |accessdate=October 20, 2016}}</ref> The festival also included a showing of ten short films in the horror, science fiction and cult genres.<ref name="tadsched"/>

revision.comment: No longer an orphan. You can help: [[WP:ORPHANAGE|WikiProject Orphanage]].
revision.text:
The '''Trenton Computer Festival''', founded in 1976, is the oldest continuously-running personal computer show in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://princetonacm.acm.org/tcfpro/|title=TCF Professional Conference|last=Soll|first=David F.|website=princetonacm.acm.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tcnjsignal.net/2015/04/01/trenton-computer-festival-in-its-40th-year/|title=Trenton Computer Festival in its 40th year|date=2015-04-01|work=The Signal|access-date=2018-03-15|language=en-US}}</ref> It is considered to be the first major fair for personal computer hobbyists.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=9oJcAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA10&dq=%22Trenton+Computer+Festival%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiM9d-goO3ZAhVFzIMKHc5IDIoQ6AEIQDAG#v=onepage&q=TCF&f=false|title=CoCo: The Colorful History of Tandy’s Underdog Computer|last=Pitre|first=Boisy G.|last2=Loguidice|first2=Bill|date=2013-12-10|publisher=CRC Press|year=|isbn=9781466592476|location=|pages=10|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=vpjpAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT17&dq=%22Trenton+Computer+Festival%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiM9d-goO3ZAhVFzIMKHc5IDIoQ6AEISzAI#v=onepage&q=TCF&f=false|title=Vintage Game Consoles: An Inside Look at Apple, Atari, Commodore, Nintendo, and the Greatest Gaming Platforms of All Time|last=Loguidice|first=Bill|last2=Barton|first2=Matt|date=2014-02-24|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=9781135006501|language=en}}</ref>
It was founded 1976 at [[Trenton State College]] by [[Sol Libes]] and [[Allen Katz (professor)|Allen Katz]] with the assistance of the [[Amateur Computer Group of New Jersey]] (ACGNJ).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/trenton-computer-festival-the-early-days-of-computing-and-me/|title=Trenton Computer Festival, the early days of computing, and me {{!}} ZDNet|last=Gewirtz|first=David|work=ZDNet|access-date=2018-03-15|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pcmag.com/encyclopedia/term/53153/trenton-computer-festival|title=Trenton Computer Festival - Definition from PC Magazine Encyclopedia|last=|first=|date=|website=www.pcmag.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-15}}</ref> The initial event drew a crowd of approximately 1,500, and featured lectures, vendor tables, and an outdoor computer market, all aimed at the amateur computer hobbyist.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1976/05/04/86368031.html?pageNumber=1|title=Low-Cost Computers Beginning to Move Into the Home|last=Rensberger|first=Boyce|date=1976-05-04|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-03-14|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|subscription=y}}</ref>
By 1992, it had moved to the [[Mercer County Community College]],<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=vL8pAQAAMAAJ&q=%22Mercer+County+Community+College%22+%22Trenton+Computer+festival%22&dq=%22Mercer+County+Community+College%22+%22Trenton+Computer+festival%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjo9_LEqO3ZAhUh9YMKHbwHBrkQ6AEILzAC|title=CQ: The Radio Amateurs' Journal|date=1992|publisher=CQ Publishing|language=en}}</ref> and by 1999 it had moved to the [[New Jersey Convention and Exposition Center]] in [[Edison, New Jersey]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=Sy5QAAAAYAAJ&q=%22New+Jersey+Convention+and+Exposition+Center%22+%22Trenton+Computer+festival%22&dq=%22New+Jersey+Convention+and+Exposition+Center%22+%22Trenton+Computer+festival%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwijnoKDqu3ZAhWnyoMKHfZlD0cQ6AEIJzAA|title=Amateur Radio|date=1999|publisher=CQ Publishing|language=en}}</ref> In 2005, TCF returned to [[The College of New Jersey]], formerly Trenton State College, to celebrate its 30th anniversary.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tcnj.edu/~pa/news/2005/TCF.htm|title=TCF|website=www.tcnj.edu|access-date=2018-03-15}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.tcf-nj.org Official website]
[[Category:Computer-related events]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1976]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox recurring event |name = TromaDance Film Festival |logo = [[Image:TromaDance.jpg]] |image = |caption = |location = [[Park City, Utah|Park City]] and [[Salt Lake City]], [[Utah]] (1999-2009)
[[Asbury Park, New Jersey|Asbury Park]], [[New Jersey]] (2010-2013)
[[New York City, New York]] (2014-present) |years_active = 1999 - present |dates = Mid-January, concurrent with the [[Sundance Film Festival]] (1999-2009)
Mid-April (2010-present) |genre = [[Independent film|Independent]] [[Feature film|feature]] and [[short film]]s |website = http://www.tromadance.com/ }} The '''TromaDance Film Festival''' is a free annual [[independent film|independent]] [[film festival]] organized by [[Troma Entertainment]]. Founded in 1999, TromaDance was originally held in [[Park City, Utah|Park City]] and [[Salt Lake City, Utah|Salt Lake City]], [[Utah]], operating concurrently alongside the [[Sundance Film Festival]] in order to showcase an independent alternative to Sundance's perceived mainstream offerings. Between 2010 and 2013, the festival had been relocated to various locations throughout [[New Jersey]]. Since 2014, TromaDance has relocated to [[New York City]]. ==Overview== {{unreferenced section|date=October 2015}} TromaDance advertises itself as "the first and only film festival of the people, for the people, and by the people", dedicated to "bringing independent art back to the people". In direct opposition to Sundance, TromaDance doesn't charge an entry fee for filmmakers to submit their films and doesn't charge admission fees for people to attend the film screenings. Although Troma themselves are notorious for their violent low-budget [[horror film]]s, TromaDance showcases both [[short film|shorts]] and features of varying genres and formats, including [[comedy film|comedy]], [[drama film|drama]], [[documentary film|documentary]], [[animation]] and [[experimental film]], though horror, fantasy and sci-fi usually make up a significant portion of the entries. TromaDance is primarily funded by donations, and the festival's employees and volunteers are entirely unpaid. TromaDance has been sponsored over the years by ''[[Filmmaker Magazine]]'', [[G4 (U.S. TV channel)|G4]], [[Jägermeister]], [[Kodak]], ''[[MovieMaker|MovieMaker Magazine]]'', [[PETA]], ''[[Rue Morgue (magazine)|Rue Morgue Magazine]]'', ''[[SLUG Magazine]]'', and [[Stella Artois]]. Troma also sponsors fan-organized events called TromaPaloozas, music festivals that serve as fundraisers for TromaDance. TromaPaloozas have been held in [[Denver, Colorado|Denver]], [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]], [[Minneapolis, Minnesota|Minneapolis]], [[Murfreesboro, Tennessee|Murfreesboro]], and [[Tulsa, Oklahoma|Tulsa]]. ==History== The idea for TromaDance was developed by Troma president [[Lloyd Kaufman]], who got the idea from ''[[South Park]]'' co-creator [[Trey Parker]] (whose debut film, ''[[Cannibal! The Musical]]'', was distributed by Troma). Feeling that Sundance had become too "Hollywood" by charging high entry fees, showing multimillion-dollar "independent" movies and practicing an elitist structure and film selection process, Parker urged Kaufman to create his own film festival that was the direct independent opposite of Sundance, one that was completely free and focused on independently produced film that was made without the Hollywood system in order to give first-time filmmakers a chance at getting their work seen. Troma has released five volumes of ''"The Best of TromaDance"'', DVDs of selected shorts each from two years worth of the festival. The press conference for the 2005 festival held in October 2004 featured the introduction of the official TromaDance Theme Song by longtime Troma character [[Count Smokula]].{{cite web|url=http://news.tromadance.com/archives/2004/10/18/press-release/|title=TromaDance News & Information|publisher=www.troma.com|date=October 18, 2004|accessdate=2008-10-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011131259/http://news.tromadance.com/archives/2004/10/18/press-release/|archivedate=October 11, 2008|df=}} =="Satellite" TromaDance festivals== *TromaDance DVD Collections (2002–present) *TromaDance Portland (in Portland, OR) (2004) *Tromanale (in [[Berlin]]) (2005 and 2006) *Tromafling (in Edinburgh) (2005) *Tromanale (in Berlin) (2005–2006) *TromaDance North (in Winnipeg, Manitoba) (2006) *TromaDance New Mexico (in [[Albuquerque]]) (2006–present) *TromaDance Indiana (in [[Franklin, IN]]) (2007–present) *Tromadance Detroit (2013–present) ==See also== * [[Brussels International Festival of Fantasy Film]] * [[Bucheon International Fantastic Film Festival]] (aka BiFan, Puchon International Fantastic Film Festival, or PiFan) in South Korea * [[Calgary Underground Film Festival]] * [[Dead by Dawn]] in Edinburgh, Scotland * [[European Fantastic Film Festivals Federation]] in Brussels, Belgium * [[Fantafestival]] in Italy * [[Fantasia International Film Festival]] in Canada * [[Fantasporto]] (aka also known as Fantas), in Porto, Portugal * [[Fantastic Fest]] in Austin, Texas * [[Festival de Cine de Sitges]] (aka [[Sitges Film Festival]]) in Spain * [[International Horror and Sci-Fi Film Festival]] in Tempe, Arizona * [[London FrightFest Film Festival]] * [[Lund International Fantastic Film Festival]] * [[New York City Horror Film Festival]] * [[Screamfest Horror Film Festival]] in Hollywood, California * [[Toronto After Dark Film Festival]] in Canada ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.tromadance.com/}} [[Category:Film festivals in New Jersey]] [[Category:Fantasy film festivals]] [[Category:Film festivals in Utah]] [[Category:Troma Entertainment films]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Utah]]

{{good article}} {{Infobox military memorial |name= United Nations Memorial Cemetery | native_name = 재한유엔기념공원 | native_name_lang = ko |body=Commission for the UNMCK (CUNMCK) |image=[[File:UN Memorial Cemetery.JPG|220px]] |caption= UNMCK Wall of Remembrance |use_dates= 1950–53
plus UNC deceased post-war |established= January 18, 1951
(as the United Nations Military Cemetery (UNMC)) |designer= |location= 93 UN Pyeonghwa-ro, [[Nam District, Busan|Nam-gu]], [[Busan]], 608-812, [[South Korea|Republic of Korea]]
(Old address: 779 Daeyon 4-dong, Nam-gu, Busan) |coordinates = {{coord|35|7|41|N|129|5|49|E|display=inline,title}} |total= 2,300 |unknowns= |by_country=[[United Nations Command (Korea)|United Nations Command (UNC)]]: * [[British Commonwealth Forces Korea]] ** [[United Kingdom]]: 885 ** [[Canada in the Korean War|Canadian]]: 378Korean War casualties only. In 2012, the cremated remains of Archie Hearsay were buried with his brother, [http://www.unmck.or.kr/eng_m_searchsol_view.php?uid=290605 Joseph], who had died in Korea while both were serving. See: {{cite news |title=Ashes of Canadian veteran buried beside brother in S. Korea |url=http://www.tbnewswatch.com/news/205114/Ashes-of-Canadian-veteran-buried-beside-brother-in-S.Korea |newspaper=TBNewsWatch (Dougall Media) |date=April 25, 2012 |agency=The Canadian Press |access-date=February 19, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224213327/http://www.tbnewswatch.com/news/205114/Ashes-of-Canadian-veteran-buried-beside-brother-in-S.Korea |archive-date=February 24, 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} ** [[Australia in the Korean War|Australian]]: 281 ** [[New Zealand in the Korean War|New Zealanders]]: 34 ** [[2 Squadron SAAF#Korean War|South Africa (2 Squadron SAAF)]]: 11{{cite book|last=Brent|first=Winston A.|title=2 Squadron in Korea: Flying Cheetahs 1950–1953|year=2001|publisher=Freeworld Publications|location=Nelspruit|isbn=978-0-9583880-9-2|page=134 |oclc=174758735}} * [[Turkish Brigade|Turkey (Turkish Brigade)]]: 462{{cite web|title=Turkish Fallen of Korean War Remembered|url=http://www.diplomaticobserver.com/EN/belge/2-2158/turkish-fallen-of-korean-war-remembered.html|work=Diplomatic Observer|publisher=Över Publishing|location=Ankara|year=2002|access-date=2014-02-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222163243/http://www.diplomaticobserver.com/EN/belge/2-2158/turkish-fallen-of-korean-war-remembered.html|archive-date=2014-02-22|dead-url=yes|df=}} * [[Military history of the Netherlands#Korean War|Dutch (the "Netherlands Battalion")]]: 117{{cite web|title=Speech at the United Nations Memorial Cemetery in Busan|url=http://www.government.nl/documents-and-publications/speeches/2010/04/29/speech-at-the-united-nations-memorial-cemetery-in-busan.html|work=Documents and publications|publisher=Government of the Netherlands|author=[[Jan Peter Balkenende|Balkenende, Jan Peter]] ([[Prime Minister of the Netherlands]]) |date=April 29, 2010}} * [[French Battalion in the Korean War|France (French Battalion)]]: 44 * [[Republic of Korea Army|South Korean]]: 36 – ROK Army soldiers serving in UNC units[http://www.unmck.or.kr/eng_un_01_4.php UNMCK: Status of Interred at the UNMCK] * [[United States|American]]: 36Post-war deaths only – with the exception of 4 symbolic unknowns, all recovered remains were repatriated.{{cite book|last=Dickon|first=Chris|title=The Foreign Burial of American War Dead: A History|year=2011|publisher=McFarland & Co.|location=Jefferson, NC|isbn=978-0-7864-4612-4|pages=138, 141 |oclc=659753667 }} * [[Norway]]: 1{{cite web|title=Korea 2007|url=http://www.kongehuset.no/artikkel.html?tid=35005&sek=30234|work=Det Norske Kongehus|date=November 28, 2007|quote=Among [the soldiers] is Norwegian Second Engineer Reidar George Tveit ... [[Haakon, Crown Prince of Norway|Crown Prince Haakon]] [also] laid a wreath at the new monument commemorating the Norwegian soldiers ...}} * [[Non-combatants]]: 11Reportedly of North Koreans who refused to be repatriated following the war because they had criticized the regime. See: {{cite book|last=Baldwin|first=R F|title=Seven Years in Asia: A Wander's Tale|year= 2013|origyear= 2011|publisher=Booksmango|isbn=978-616-245-096-9 |page=278 | oclc= 781689455}} * Unknown: 4Some unidentified Americans were left as token representatives to the unknowns. {{cite book|last=Pash|first=Melinda L.|title=In the Shadow of the Greatest Generation: the Americans who fought the Korean War|year=2012|publisher=New York University|location=New York and London|isbn=978-0-8147-6769-6|page=134 |oclc=777627052}} |source=
* [http://www.unmck.or.kr/eng_index.php UN Memorial Cemetery (Official)]
* [http://www.koreanwarmemorials.org/domestic/united-nations/united-nations-memorial-cemetery-in-korea/ Korean War Memorials: UN Memorial Cemetery in Korea] }} {{Infobox Korean name | hangul = {{linktext|재한|유엔|기념|공원}} | hanja = 재한유엔{{linktext|記念|公園}} | rr = Jaehan yuen ginyumgongwon | mr = Chaehan yuen kinyŏmgongwŏn }} The '''United Nations Memorial Cemetery in Korea''' ('''UNMCK'''; {{Korean|hangul=재한유엔기념공원|rr=Jaehahn yuen ginyeomgongwon}}),[http://www.unmck.or.kr/eng_index.php United Nations Memorial Cemetery, Korea] located at Tanggok in the [[Nam District, Busan|Nam District]],{{cite web|title=Pusan (Korea) 1959|url=http://collections.lib.uwm.edu/cdm/ref/collection/agdm/id/688|publisher=[[University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries Digital Collections#Holdings of the American Geographical Society Library|American Geographical Society Library Digital Map Collection]]|author=1901st Engr. Topo. Bn., ROK Army|quote=Boundary Line Plan United Nations Memorial Cemetery}}; also see: [http://www.koreanwar2.org/kwp2/maps/l751_pdf/korean_war_project_smu_363.pdf Korea 1:50,000 Pusan Sheet 7019 III (1947)] and [http://www.koreanwar.org/html/korean_war_maps_results.html?id=259 Pusan – 1947 – AMS Map Sheet L751 – 7109 III] [[Busan|City of Busan]],As a transliteration from [[Korean language|Korean]], the city name 부산 ({{IPA-ko|pusʰan}}) was typically spelled "Pusan" in [[McCune-Reischauer]] until 2000. The official [[Revised Romanization]] spells the name Busan. See {{cite web|url=http://geographic.org/geographic_names/name.php?uni=-1007276&fid=3437&c=south_korea |title=Pusan: South Korea |work=Geographical Names |accessdate=August 15, 2011}} [[South Korea|Republic of Korea]], is a burial ground for [[United Nations Command]] (UNC) [[Killed in action|casualties]] of the [[Korean War]].The Korean War started on June 25, 1950 when North Korean forces pushed south of the [[38th parallel north#Korea|38th parallel]] which [[Division of Korea|divided Korea]] following World War II. With authorization from the United Nations, forces from the United States and other nations pushed the North Koreans back to the north. When these UN forces approached China, Chinese forces intervened and the battlefront eventually stabilized along the 38th parallel. The [[s:Korean Armistice Agreement|Korean Armistice]] was signed on July 27, 1953 to end the fighting. It contains 2,300 graves and is the only [[United Nations]] cemetery in the world. Laid out over {{convert|14|hectare}}, the graves are set out in 22 sites designated by the nationalities of the buried servicemembers.{{cite book|last=Clark|first=Donald N.|title=The [[Seoul Foreigners' Cemetery at Yanghwajin]] |chapter-url=http://seoul4ncemetery.org/documents/YANGHWAJIN_DonClark.pdf |date=September 1996 |publisher=Seoul Union Church|location=Seoul, Korea|page=78|chapter=Part III: Smaller Foreign Cemeteries in the Provinces}} == History == === Temporary battlefield cemeteries and remains recovery === The [[Korean War]] began when [[Korean People's Army Ground Force#History|North Korean People's Army]] forces attacked south in June 1950. As the fighting progressed, temporary [[War grave|military cemeteries]] for battle casualties were established by United Nations forces near the towns of [[Taejon]] (July 9, 1950), Kwan-ui (Kwan-ni),{{cite book|editor-last=Westover |editor-first=John G. |author=Cooper, Marcus E. |title=Combat Support in Korea|year=1990|publisher=[[Center for Military History]]|location=Washington, DC|url=http://www.koreanwar2.org/kwp2/cmh/combat_support_in_korea.pdf|chapter=Part VII: Quartermaster Corps: 1: Division Supply Operations|pages=141–50}}
{{cite book|editor-last=Westover |editor-first=John G. |author=Kurtz, Jacob W. |title=Combat Support in Korea|year=1990|publisher=[[Center for Military History]]|location=Washington, DC|url=http://www.koreanwar2.org/kwp2/cmh/combat_support_in_korea.pdf|chapter=Part VII: Quartermaster Corps: 12: Pukchon Cemetery |pages=180–83}} Kum-chon, and [[Chilgok County|Sindong]].{{cite journal |last=Cook |first=James C. |title=Graves Registration in the Korean Conflict |journal=The Quartermaster Review |date=March–April 1953 |url=http://www.qmmuseum.lee.army.mil/korea/gr_korea.htm |publisher=Army Quartermaster Museum |location=Fort Lee, VA}} When the North Korean forces pushed towards Pusan, these cemeteries had to be abandoned. Later, as the [[Battle of Pusan Perimeter]] developed, temporary cemeteries were established at [[Masan]], [[Miryang]], and [[Taegu]], with a Pusan cemetery being established on July 11, 1950. As the fighting pushed into North Korea, temporary cemeteries were established in or near the towns of [[Kaesong]], [[Sukehon]], [[Wonsan]], [[Pupchong]] ([[Pukchong County]]), [[Battle of Chosin Reservoir#Battle|Yudarn-ni and Koto-ri]].{{cite journal |last=Cannon |first=Florence |title=Our Honored Dead |journal=The Quartermaster Review |date=May–June 1952 |url=http://www.memorialdayfoundation.org/articles/our-honored-dead.html |publisher=United States Quartermaster Museum & The Memorial Day Foundation |quote= [After July 1950], reports of burials were received from cemeteries in the Miryang, Taegu, Kaesong, Pyongyang, Sukehon, Wonsan, Pupchong, Hungnam, Yudarn, Koto-ri and Tanggok areas.}} Some 11 division-level cemeteries were established in the first two months of fighting{{cite journal|last=Anders|first=Steven E.|title=With All Due Honors: A History of the Quartermaster Graves Registration Mission|journal=Quartermaster Professional Bulletin|date=September 1988|url=http://www.qmfound.com/grave.htm|access-date=2014-03-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102221327/http://qmfound.com/grave.htm|archive-date=2013-11-02|dead-url=yes|df=}} and later 5 UN military cemeteries were established in North Korea.{{cite web|title=POW March Routes and United Nations Cemeteries [map] |url=http://www.dtic.mil/dpmo/korea/maps/images/map_routes.jpg |publisher=[[Defense POW/Missing Personnel Office]]}}[[File:Graves registration service - korea.gif|left|thumbnail|A corporal from the 114th Graves Registration Co. fills out a Form 52B, giving information regarding a deceased American soldier at the U.N. Cemetery at [[Daegu, South Korea|Taegu]]. Nearby are a cross, a triangular unidentified soldier marker, and small bottle containing Form 1042 which is buried with the casualty. (US Army Photo, January 23, 1951)]] At the beginning of the war, the nearest U.S. Army [[Mortuary Affairs#Korean War|mortuary affairs]] unit was the 108th Graves Registration Platoon in [[Yokohama, Japan]], which was searching for the remains of missing World War II American airmen.{{cite journal|last=Coleman|first=Bradley Lynn|title=Recovering the Korean War Dead, 1950–1958: Graves Registration, Forensic Anthropology, and Wartime Memorialization|journal=[[The Journal of Military History]]|date=January 2008|volume=72|issue=1|pages=179–222|publisher=Project Muse ([[Society for Military History]]) |issn=0899-3718 |url= http://www.smh-hq.org/jmh/jmhvols/721.html|doi=10.1353/jmh.2008.0013 }}{{cite book |last=Potter |first=Constance |title=A Companion to American Military History, Vol II |year=2010 |publisher=Wiley-Blackwell |isbn=978-1-4051-6149-7 |page=1039 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=6TctrNS2-34C&pg=PA1039&lpg=PA1039&dq=Tanggok+Pusan#v=onepage&q=Tanggok%20Pusan&f=false |author2=Deeben, John |editor= [[James C. Bradford|Bradford, James C.]] |chapter=67: Care for the Military Dead | oclc=316098909 }}The only other American [[active duty]] graves registration unit was at [[Ft. Bragg, North Carolina]]. {{cite journal|last=Becker|first=James R.|title=United States Culture and Its Effects on Military Policy Regarding Mortuary Affairs |year=2004 |url=http://oai.dtic.mil/oai/oai?verb=getRecord&metadataPrefix=html&identifier=ADA428539 |publisher=[[US Army Command and General Staff College]] |location=Ft. Leavenworth, KS}} The 108th was reconfigured as the 114th Graves Registration Company and deployed to establish temporary cemeteries at [[Hungnam]], [[Pyongyang]], and Suchon as the fighting continued. Supporting the [[2nd Infantry Division (United States)#Korean War|2nd Infantry Division]] was the Graves Registration Section of the 2nd Quartermaster Company, which collected the remains of Allied and American soldiers to be further processed by the 148th Graves Registration Company.{{cite book |last=Alexander |first=Bevin R. |title=Combat Support in Korea |year=1951 |publisher=[[U.S. Army Center of Military History]] |url=http://www.history.army.mil/documents/Korea/KW-MHD/BA-60/ba-60.htm|chapter=Quartermaster Field Service Platoon in Action}} When UN forces launched the [[Inchon Invasion]] in September 1950, a platoon from the 565th Graves Registration Company accompanied them. Other mortuary affairs units included the 293rd Graves Registration Company, activated in April 1951. It was difficult to recover remains and conduct burials in Korea, due to the rugged geography and harsh climate, and the threat of [[unexploded ordnance]] and [[booby-traps]].{{cite book |last=Sledge |first=Michael |title=Soldier Dead: How We Recover, Identify, Bury, and Honor Our Military Fallen |year= 2007|origyear= 2005 |publisher=Columbia University Press |location=New York |pages=40–41, 58, 80, 190 |isbn=978-0-231-50937-4 |oclc= 60527603 }} === Construction of the Tanggok cemetery === Construction of the United Nations Military Cemetery (UNMC) at Tanggok began on January 18, 1951 and was carried out by hand-labor over a {{convert|28.2|hectare}} site.{{cite journal|last=Keene|first=Judith|title=Below Ground: The Treatment of American Remains from the Korean War|journal=[[The Public Historian]]|date=February 2010|volume=32|issue=1|pages=58–78|doi=10.1525/tph.2010.32.1.59|jstor=10.1525/tph.2010.32.1.59|publisher=[[National Council on Public History]]|issn=0272-3433}} It was dedicated by General [[Matthew Ridgway]] on April 6, 1951.{{cite web|title=UN Memorial Cemetery |url=http://eng.koreanwar60.go.kr/20/2005000000.asp |publisher=The 60th Anniversary of the Korean War Commemoration Committee |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615125844/http://eng.koreanwar60.go.kr/20/2005000000.asp |archivedate=June 15, 2013 }} Graves Registration units then concentrated American and allied remains at Tanggok before they were permanently buried or repatriated. Besides burial services, refrigeration units to store remains were added, as were cremation facilities.Casualties from the [[National Army of Colombia#Korean War|Colombia Battalion]] were cremated at Tanggok by the American Graves Registration Service and then repatriated to Colombia in 1954. {{cite journal |last=Coleman |first=Bradley Lynn |title=The Colombian Army in Korea, 1950–1954 |journal=[[The Journal of Military History]] |date=October 2005 |volume=69 |issue=4 |pages=1166–67 |publisher=Project Muse ([[Society for Military History]]) |issn=0899-3718 |url= http://muse.jhu.edu/login?auth=0&type=summary&url=/journals/journal_of_military_history/v069/69.4coleman.pdf |doi=10.1353/jmh.2005.0215 }} Today the 2,300 graves in the cemetery are set out in 22 sites designated by the nationalities of the buried service members. === Post-armistice === Following the signing of the [[Korean Armistice Agreement]] in July 1953, the United Nations Command sought to recover bodies interred in North Korean territory.{{cite web|title=Major Remains Concentrations in North Korea |url=http://www.dtic.mil/dpmo/korea/maps/documents/Major%20Remains%20Concentrations%20in%20North%20Korea.pdf |publisher=[[Defense POW/Missing Personnel Office]]}}; {{cite web|title=POW March Routes and U.N. Cemeteries |url=http://www.dtic.mil/dpmo/korea/maps/documents/POW%20March%20Routes%20and%20UN%20Cemeteries.pdf |publisher=[[Defense POW/Missing Personnel Office]]}} Cemeteries for POWs in North Korea were established at 16 POW camps.{{cite web|title=Major Remains Concentrations in North Korea [map] |url=http://www.dtic.mil/dpmo/korea/maps/images/map_remains07.jpg |publisher=[[Defense POW/Missing Personnel Office]]}} From September to October 1954, the resulting exchange of casualties, dubbed [[Operation Glory]], between United Nations forces and the North Koreans resulted in 4,219 remains being recovered, of which 1,275 were non-US casualties.{{cite journal |title=Operation GLORY: Historical Summary |journal=Condensed from Graves Registration Division, Korean Communications Zone (KCOMZ) |date=Jul–Dec 2004 |url=http://www.qmmuseum.lee.army.mil/korea/op_glory.htm|publisher=Army Quartermaster Museum|location=Fort Lee, VA}} Note: the calculation of remains comes from Coleman as the "Historical Summary" gives a total of 4,023 UN remains received. (Also exchanged were the remains of approximately 14,000 North Korean and Chinese casualties.){{cite book |last=Cole |first=Paul M. |title=POW/MIA Issues Volume 1, The Korean War |year=1994 |publisher=National Defense Research Institute |location=Santa Monica, CA |isbn=978-0-8330-1482-5 |page=68 |url=https://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/monograph_reports/2006/MR351.1.pdf |chapter=Three: Efforts to Recover and Account for Korean War Casualties |oclc = 855303293}} From 1950 to 1954, approximately 11,000 casualties were interred at UNMC, which was maintained by the United States Army Graves Registration Agency.{{cite book|last=Nahm|first=Andrew W.|title=Historical Dictionary of the Republic of Korea |year=2004 |publisher=Scarecrow Press |location=Lantham, MD |isbn=0-8108-4949-6 |page=173|author2=Hoare, James E. |oclc=54081516}}{{cite journal|title=Conference Series: Canada and the United Nations|year=1956|page=15|author=Department of External Affairs |location=Ottawa |oclc=}} === Foundation as a United Nations cemetery and transfer to CUNMCK === It was officially established as the United Nations Memorial Cemetery on December 15, 1955 with the passage of [[UN General Assembly Resolution]] 977(X).{{cite web|title=977(X). Establishment and maintenance of a United Nations Memorial Cemetery in Korea|url=http://www.worldlii.org/int/other/UNGARsn/1955/73.pdf|work=General Assembly – Tenth Session; 557th plenary meeting|publisher=United Nations|pages=37–38|date=December 15, 1955}}; also see: [https://books.google.com/books?id=c7DXRhwHaVQC&pg=PA554&lpg=PA554&dq=united+nations+memorial+cemetery+korea&source=bl&ots=2CHEhvRzqu&sig=mwGgXe4AlaHqZWvovoi7rbmaQAE&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ubReUtDiM4qIiALziYGwDA&ved=0CFQQ6AEwAzgo#v=onepage&q=united%20nations%20memorial%20cemetery%20korea&f=false ''United Nations Juridical Yearbook 2003'']. p. 554. {{ISBN|978-92-1-133767-9}} Following the war, the cemetery was funded from the United Nations budget, but the Sino-Soviet world objected to this funding.{{cite journal |last=Gareau |first=Frederick H. |title=The Soviet Bloc and the United Nations System: the Quantitative Record |journal=[[Political Research Quarterly]] |date=June 1972 |volume=25 |issue=2 |pages=268–94 |doi=10.1177/106591297202500209}}{{cite book |last=Lee |first=Chae-Jin |title=China and Korea: Dynamic Relations |year=1996 |publisher=Hoover Press |location=Stanford, CA |page=116 | isbn=978-0-8179-9421-1 |author2=Park, Doo-Bok |oclc= 34151310}} In 1973, the cemetery was transferred from the UN to the Commission for the United Nations Memorial Cemetery (CUNMCK), which is composed of representatives from the 11 countries who have servicemembers buried there.{{cite web |title=Cemeteries overseas |url=http://www.dva.gov.au/commems_oawg/OAWG/remembering_war_dead/Pages/korean%20war.aspx |work=Korean War |publisher=[[Australia Department of Veterans' Affairs]] |date=September 30, 2012 |access-date=October 22, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022034318/http://www.dva.gov.au/commems_oawg/OAWG/remembering_war_dead/Pages/korean%20war.aspx |archive-date=October 22, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} === Cultural heritage and tourism === The cemetery is designated as Site 359 in the listing of Registered Cultural Heritage Sites in Korea by the [[Cultural Heritage Administration of Korea]].{{cite web|title=UN Commemoration Park in Korea|url=http://english.cha.go.kr/english/search_plaza_new/EMapResultView.jsp?VdkVgwKey=79,03590000,21&strGuCode=17&strSidoCode=21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222215521/http://english.cha.go.kr/english/search_plaza_new/EMapResultView.jsp?VdkVgwKey=79,03590000,21&strGuCode=17&strSidoCode=21|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2014-02-22|work=Registered Cultural Heritage Site 359|publisher=[[Cultural Heritage Administration of Korea]]}} Also, it is a visitor attraction for [[Pacific Rim]] tourists.{{cite book|last=Hutchinson|first=Garrie|title=Pilgrimage: A Traveler's Guide to Australia's Battlefields|year=2006|publisher=Black Inc.|location=Melbourne|isbn=978-1-86395-387-0 |page=384 |oclc=234310738}}{{cite book|last=Hall|first=Colin Michael|title=Tourism in the Pacific Rim: Development, Impacts, and Markets|year=1994|publisher=Longman Cheshire|location=Melbourne|isbn=978-0-470-23375-7|page=48|oclc=258617555 }} In 2011, [[United Nations Secretary-General]] [[Ban Ki-Moon]] described it as the only United Nations cemetery in the world.{{cite web|last=Ban|first=Ki-Moon|title=Remarks at UN Memorial Cemetery in Korea [as delivered] |url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/infocus/sgspeeches/statments_full.asp?statID=1398#.UnMXkZR4Ya7 |work= [[Ban Ki-Moon]]'s speeches |publisher=UN News Center |date=November 30, 2011}} == Memorials == [[File:A little Korean girl places a wreath of flowers on the grave of an American soldier, while Private First Class... - NARA - 530634.tif|right|thumbnail|250px|April 1951 – a Korean girl places a wreath of flowers while an honour guard [[Present arms (command)|present arms]] at the United Nations cemetery in Pusan.]] An [[Guard of honour|Honour Guard]] from the [[Republic of Korea Army#Second Operational Command (육군 제2작전사령부)|Republic of Korea 53rd Division]] carries out [[Flag-raising ceremony#Hoisting the flag|flag ceremonies]] daily.{{cite web|title=Korea Vet News|url=http://france-coree.pagesperso-orange.fr/eurokorvet/uk/can_newslet.htm|publisher=Korean War Commemoration Council of Canada}} The UN Sculpture Park was established in October 2001 and twenty-nine permanent memorials are in the cemetery.{{cite web|title=UN Sculpture Park|url=http://southafrica-embassy.or.kr/eng/sankorea/korean_war(UNMCK).php|work=UNMCK|publisher=Republic of South Africa Embassy}} The memorials include: * [[Commonwealth of Nations]] memorials: ** Australian Memorial{{cite web|title=Remembering the Korean War|url=http://www.defenceanglicans.org.au/remembering-the-korean-war/|work=Ministry Stories|publisher=Defence Anglicans|accessdate=November 9, 2013|year=2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109175459/http://www.defenceanglicans.org.au/remembering-the-korean-war/|archive-date=November 9, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ** British Memorial – dedicated 2010[http://www.unmck.or.kr/pop/eng_un_02_35.php UNMCK: British Memorial] ** Monument to Canadian Fallen – an identical monument is located in downtown [[Ottawa]]{{cite web|title=Monument to Canadian Fallen (Korean War Monument)|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/eng/1380645149037|work=Public Art and Monuments|publisher=[[Canadian Heritage]], Government of Canada|date=October 25, 2013}}{{cite web|title=Canadian Korean War Veterans Participate in a Remembrance Ceremony at the United Nations Memorial Cemetery in the Republic of Korea|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/canadian-korean-war-veterans-participate-in-a-remembrance-ceremony-at-the-united-nations-memorial-cemetery-in-the-republic-of-korea-217300351.html|publisher=PR Newswire|date=July 28, 2013|quote=[T]he names of the 516 Canadian soldiers who died ... are written on the Wall of Remembrance.}} ** Commonwealth Memorial{{cite book|last=Summers|first=Julie|title=British and Commonwealth War Cemeteries|year=2010|publisher=Shire Publications|location=Oxford, UK|isbn=978-0-7478-0789-6|page=50|url=https://books.google.com/?id=PnT_8yIcTNAC&pg=PA50&lpg=PA50&dq=united+nations+memorial+cemetery+korea#v=onepage&q=united%20nations%20memorial%20cemetery%20korea&f=false|chapter=Commemoration of the War Dead Since 1945 |oclc=462882226 }} *** Commonwealth Missing in Action Memorial ** New Zealand Memorial – designed by [[Warren and Mahoney]] architects and built of marble from the [[Coromandel Peninsula]]{{cite web|title=New Zealand Memorial in Korea|url=http://www.mch.govt.nz/nz-identity-heritage/national-monuments-war-graves/new-zealand-memorial-korea|work=National monuments & war graves|publisher=NZ Identity & Heritage|date=February 19, 2013}}{{cite web|title=Veterans To Attend Korean War Armistice Commemoration|url=http://www.airforce.mil.nz/about-us/news/media-releases/media-release.htm@guid=%7Ba12c2901-9c7c-47de-8c83-ce061ec99d62%7D.htm|work=Media Releases|publisher=New Zealand Defence Force|date=June 2013}} ** South Africa Memorial – the 2001 sculpture ''Reconciliation'' by South African sculptor [[Strijdom van der Merwe]], was created as part of the [[International Sculpture Symposium]] * French Memorial – dedicated 2007[http://www.unmck.or.kr/pop/eng_un_02_34.php UNMCK: French Memorial]{{cite journal|last=Quisefit|first=Laurent|title=The French Participation in the Korean War and the Establishment of a 'Path of Memory' in South Korea|journal=Societies|date=November 5, 2013|volume=3|issue=4|pages=427–44|doi=10.3390/soc3040427|url=http://www.mdpi.com/2075-4698/3/4/427|issn=2075-4698}} * Greek Memorial – dedicated 1961[http://www.unmck.or.kr/pop/eng_un_02_23.php UNMCK: Greek Memorial] * Interfaith memorial chapel – built by the United Nations Command in 1964 * Main gate – designed by Korean architect [[Kim Joong-up]] and built by the city of Busan in 1966. The end of the eight pillars supporting the roof was designed as a bowl and a symbol representing the moment and the eternity, expressing a soft and solemn standing for the soldiers. * Memorabilia display hall – built by the UN in 1968 * Norwegian Memorial{{cite web|title=Vice Minister [Foreign Affairs, Torgeir Larsen] Visits United Nations Memorial Cemetery in Korea|url=http://www.norway.or.kr/News_and_events/Current-affairs/News/Vice-Minister-Visits-United-Nations-Memorial-Cemetery-in-Korea/#.UmQBjJR4adO|publisher=The Royal Norwegian Embassy in Seoul|date= October 4, 2013}} * Thai Memorial – dedicated November 2008{{cite web|title=Bilateral Relations: Military cooperation|url=http://www.thaiembassy.org/seoul/en/relation|publisher=Royal Thai Embassy, Seoul|date=May 2, 2013}} * Turkish Memorials I and II – dedicated 1960, 1962, and 2008{{cite web|title=South Koreans, allies pay tribute to Turkish war effort|url=http://defence.pk/threads/south-koreans-allies-pay-tribute-to-turkish-war-effort.63383/|work=Daily News|publisher=Pakistan Defence|date=June 27, 2010}}[http://www.unmck.or.kr/pop/eng_un_02_21.php UNMCK: Turkish Memorial I]; [http://www.unmck.or.kr/pop/eng_un_02_22.php UNMCK: Turkish Memorial II] * UN Forces Monument – dedicated 1978 and refurbished in 2007[http://www.unmck.or.kr/pop/eng_un_02_42.php UNMCK: UN Forces Monument] * United States Korean War Memorial – the [[Frank Gaylord]] sculpture was carved from [[Barre Granite]] at the [[Rock of Ages Corporation]] in [[Barre (town), Vermont|Barre, Vermont]], and dedicated under the auspices of the [[American Battle Monuments Commission]] in 2013{{cite web |title=Dedication of the U.S. Korean War Memorial in Busan, South Korea on July 28 |url=http://www.abmc.gov/events/KWMemorial.php |work=Events: |publisher=[[American Battle Monuments Commission]] |date=July 22, 2013 |quote=This is the third memorial commemorating the Korean War created by ABMC. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022044209/http://www.abmc.gov/events/KWMemorial.php |archivedate=October 22, 2013 |df= }}[http://www.abmc.gov/memorials/memorials/kw.php Korean War Monument at Busan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029204923/http://www.abmc.gov/memorials/memorials/kw.php |date=2013-10-29 }}{{cite web|last=Delcore|first=David|title=Barre granite is new, unique memorial in South Korea|url=http://www.vermonttoday.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/RH/20130928/NEWS01/709289956|work=Vermont Today|publisher=Rutland Herald|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222190100/http://www.vermonttoday.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2FRH%2F20130928%2FNEWS01%2F709289956|archivedate=2014-02-22|df=}} * The Unknown Soldiers' Pathway{{Cite web |url=http://www.koreanwarmemorials.org/domestic/united-nations/united-nations-memorial-cemetery-in-korea/ |title=Korean War Memorials: UN Memorial Cemetery in Korea |access-date=2013-10-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019083127/http://www.koreanwarmemorials.org/domestic/united-nations/united-nations-memorial-cemetery-in-korea/ |archive-date=2013-10-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }} The Wall of Remembrance, completed in 2006, has the names of the 40,896 United Nations casualties (killed and missing) inscribed on 140 marble panels.[http://www.unmck.or.kr/pop/eng_un_02_45.php UNMCK: Wall of Remembrance] The UNMCK maintains a website in [[Korean language|Korean]], [[English language|English]], and [[Turkish language|Turkish (Türkçe)]], which allows website visitors to post online flowers and tributary messages.[http://www.unmck.or.kr/eng_memory_07.php UNMCK: Cyber Flower Dedications] and [http://www.unmck.or.kr/bbs/board.php?bo_table=letter_eng UNMCK: Tributary Message] == Notable graves == [[File:Ereveld Tanggok.jpg|left|thumbnail|225px|The grounds today]] The cemetery contains the graves of 2,289 military personnel and 11 non-combatants. Amongst those are the graves of [[Bill Madden (GC)|Bill Madden GC]], 3rd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment, (who died as a prisoner of war), [[Kenneth Muir (VC)|Kenneth Muir VC]] (killed in action in the [[Battle of Hill 282]] while serving with the [[Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders]]),{{cite web|url=http://www.unmck.or.kr/eng_m_searchsol_view.php?uid=340806|title=Major Muir, K.|publisher=UN Memorial Cemetery, Korea}} and [[Philip Curtis]] VC (killed in action in the [[Battle of the Imjin River]] while serving with [[The Duke of Cornwall's Light Infantry]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.unmck.or.kr/eng_m_searchsol_view.php?uid=331009|title=Lt. Curtis, P.K.E.|publisher=UN Memorial Cemetery, Korea}} Also buried is Lt. Col. [[Charles Hercules Green]] DSO, commander of the [[3rd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]], who was mortally wounded at [[Battle of Chongju (1950)|Battle of Chongju]] and died at nearby [[Anju, South Pyongan|Anju]].{{cite web|url=http://www.unmck.or.kr/eng_m_searchsol_view.php?uid=350810|title=Lt. Col. Green, Charles Hercules|publisher=UN Memorial Cemetery, Korea}} Dutch Lt. Col. [[:nl:Marinus Petrus Antonius den Ouden|Marinus Petrus Antonius den Ouden]], commander of the [[Regiment Van Heutsz]], was killed in action during [[Operation Roundup (1951)|Operation Roundup]] in 1951 and is buried with members of his regiment—posthumously, den Ouden was awarded Netherlands' highest military award, the [[Military Order of William]].{{cite web|url=http://www.unmck.or.kr/eng_m_searchsol_view.php?uid=100301|title=Lt. Kol. Cdt. Ouden, M.P.A. den|publisher=UN Memorial Cemetery, Korea}} In the early days of the war, journalist [[Christopher Buckley (journalist)|Christopher Buckley]] died from a land mine explosion, and was subsequently buried at the cemetery.{{cite web|url=http://www.unmck.or.kr/eng_m_searchsol_view.php?uid=311002#|title=Mr. Buckley, C.|publisher=UN Memorial Cemetery, Korea}} == Total burials == Between 1951 and 1954 there were about 11,000 burials of UN troops in 21 countries. As of 2012, there are 2,300 wards of eleven countries, including 36 of the [[Republic of Korea]] troops deployed to the [[United Nations]] military bases. Because burials of seven counties graves were retrieved back to their homeland, including Belgium, Colombia, Ethiopia, Greece, Luxembourg, Philippines and Thailand.{{cite web|url=http://unmck.or.kr/kor_un_01_4.php |title= United Nations Memorial Cemetery |publisher= unmck.or.kr /|date= |accessdate=2017-09-08 |language= Korean}} The burials of [[British Commonwealth Forces Korea]] are located in United Nations Memorial Cemetery.
